canonical_explanation.text: Work done by a constant force is W = F·d = Fd cos θ, where θ is the angle between force and displacement. Work is positive when force and displacement are in the same direction, negative when opposite, and zero when perpendicular (like centripetal force). For a variable force, W = ∫F·dx. The SI unit of work is joule (1 J = 1 N·m). Kinetic energy is KE = ½mv². The work-energy theorem states that the net work done on a body equals the change in its kinetic energy: W_net = ΔKE = ½mv² − ½mu². Potential energy is the energy stored by virtue of position or configuration. Gravitational PE = mgh (near Earth's surface). Elastic PE of a spring = ½kx² (Hooke's law: F = −kx). A conservative force is one for which work done is path-independent (gravity, spring force); a non-conservative force is path-dependent (friction). The total mechanical energy E = KE + PE is conserved when only conservative forces do work. Power is the rate of doing work: P = dW/dt = F·v. Average power = W/t. The SI unit is watt (1 W = 1 J/s). In elastic collisions, both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved. In perfectly inelastic collisions, the bodies stick together and only momentum is conserved. The coefficient of restitution e = (v₂ − v₁)/(u₁ − u₂); e = 1 for elastic, e = 0 for perfectly inelastic collisions.
rules: Work: W = Fd cos θ; positive if θ < 90°, negative if θ > 90°, zero if θ = 90°.
Work-energy theorem: W_net = ΔKE = ½mv² − ½mu².
Gravitational PE: U = mgh; Elastic PE: U = ½kx².
Conservation of energy: KE + PE = constant (if only conservative forces act).
Power: P = dW/dt = F·v; unit is watt (W).
Perfectly inelastic: bodies stick, v = (m₁u₁ + m₂u₂)/(m₁ + m₂).
Coefficient of restitution: e = relative speed of separation / relative speed of approach.

questions.question_text: Work done is defined as:
questions.explanation_correct: Work W = F·d = Fd cos θ, where θ is the angle between force and displacement vectors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Force × velocity is power. Force × time is impulse. Work = Fd cos θ.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of work is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of work is the joule (J), where 1 J = 1 N·m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Newton is force, watt is power, pascal is pressure. Work is measured in joules.

questions.question_text: Work done by a force perpendicular to the displacement is:
questions.explanation_correct: W = Fd cos 90° = 0. A force perpendicular to displacement does no work.
questions.explanation_incorrect: cos 90° = 0, so work = 0. This is why centripetal force does no work.

questions.question_text: A force of 10 N displaces a body by 5 m along its direction. The work done is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: When force and displacement are in the same direction, W = Fd = 10 × 5 = 50 J.

questions.question_text: A coolie carries a load on his head and walks horizontally. The work done by the load against gravity is:
questions.explanation_correct: The displacement is horizontal while gravity acts vertically. θ = 90°, so W = mg × d × cos 90° = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since the load moves horizontally, the displacement is perpendicular to gravity, making work against gravity zero.

questions.question_text: A force F = (3î + 4ĵ) N acts on a body producing a displacement d = (4î − 3ĵ) m. The work done is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: W = F·d = 3×4 + 4×(−3) = 0 J. The force is perpendicular to the displacement.

questions.question_text: A body is displaced from (0, 0) to (3, 4) m under a force F = (2î + 5ĵ) N. The work done is:
questions.explanation_correct: Displacement = 3î + 4ĵ. W = F·d = 2(3) + 5(4) = 6 + 20 = 26 J.

questions.question_text: The work done by the gravitational force on a body of mass 2 kg falling freely through 10 m is (g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_correct: W = mgh = 2 × 10 × 10 = 200 J. Positive because gravity and displacement are in the same direction (downward).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Force (mg) and displacement are both downward, so work is positive: W = 2 × 10 × 10 = 200 J.

questions.question_text: The kinetic energy of a body of mass 4 kg moving at 3 m/s is:
questions.explanation_correct: KE = ½mv² = ½ × 4 × 9 = 18 J.

questions.question_text: The work-energy theorem states that:

options.text: Net work = change in kinetic energy
Net work = change in total energy

questions.explanation_correct: The work-energy theorem: the net work done by all forces equals the change in kinetic energy of the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: W_net = ΔKE = ½mv² − ½mu². This is the work-energy theorem.

questions.question_text: A body of mass 2 kg has its velocity increased from 5 m/s to 10 m/s. The work done on the body is:
If the kinetic energy of a body is doubled, its momentum becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: KE = p²/(2m). If KE doubles, p² doubles, so p becomes √2 times.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since p = √(2mKE), doubling KE gives p' = √(2m × 2KE) = √2 × p.

questions.question_text: A bullet of mass 10 g moving at 400 m/s penetrates a wall and emerges at 100 m/s. The work done by the wall on the bullet is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: W = ½m(v²−u²) = ½×0.01×(10000−160000) = −750 J. Negative because the wall decelerates the bullet.

questions.question_text: Two bodies of masses m and 4m have equal kinetic energies. The ratio of their momenta is:
questions.explanation_correct: p = √(2mKE). For equal KE: p₁/p₂ = √(m/4m) = √(1/4) = 1/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since p = √(2mKE) and KE is the same, p₁/p₂ = √(m₁/m₂) = √(m/4m) = 1/2.

questions.question_text: The gravitational potential energy of a body of mass 5 kg at a height of 10 m is (g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gravitational PE = mgh = 5 × 10 × 10 = 500 J.

questions.question_text: The elastic potential energy stored in a spring of spring constant 200 N/m compressed by 0.1 m is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Elastic PE = ½kx² = 0.5 × 200 × 0.01 = 1 J.

questions.question_text: A spring with k = 100 N/m is stretched from its natural length by 0.2 m. If it is further stretched to 0.4 m from natural length, the additional work done is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Additional work = ½k(x₂² − x₁²) = 50(0.16 − 0.04) = 6 J. Not ½k(Δx)².

questions.question_text: A body of mass 1 kg is thrown vertically upward with velocity 20 m/s. Its potential energy at the highest point is (g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_correct: At highest point, all KE converts to PE. PE = ½mu² = ½ × 1 × 400 = 200 J. Or: H = u²/(2g) = 20 m, PE = mgh = 1 × 10 × 20 = 200 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By energy conservation, PE at top = KE at bottom = ½mv² = ½ × 1 × 400 = 200 J.

questions.question_text: The force constant of a spring is 500 N/m. The work required to stretch it from 0.05 m to 0.1 m beyond natural length is:
The potential energy of a spring when compressed by x is U. If it is compressed by 2x, the potential energy becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: PE = ½kx². If x doubles, PE = ½k(2x)² = 4 × ½kx² = 4U.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since PE ∝ x², doubling the compression gives 4 times the PE.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a conservative force?
questions.explanation_correct: Gravitational force is conservative — work done depends only on initial and final positions, not the path taken.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Friction, air resistance, and viscous drag are non-conservative. Only gravity (and spring force) are conservative.

questions.question_text: The total mechanical energy of a system is conserved when:
questions.explanation_correct: Mechanical energy (KE + PE) is conserved when only conservative forces do work on the system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Non-conservative forces (friction) convert mechanical energy to heat, so energy is not conserved in that form.

questions.question_text: A ball is dropped from 20 m. Its speed just before hitting the ground is (g = 10 m/s², no air resistance):
questions.explanation_correct: By energy conservation: mgh = ½mv². v = √(2gh) = √(2 × 10 × 20) = √400 = 20 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: PE converts to KE: v = √(2gh) = √(400) = 20 m/s.

questions.question_text: A pendulum bob is released from height h. Its speed at the lowest point is:
questions.explanation_correct: By conservation of energy: mgh = ½mv². v = √(2gh).
questions.explanation_incorrect: All PE at height h converts to KE at the lowest point: v = √(2gh).

questions.question_text: A block slides down a rough inclined plane of height 5 m. If 50% of the initial PE is lost to friction, the speed at the bottom is (g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_correct: 50% of mgh goes to KE: ½mgh = ½mv². v = √(gh) = √(10 × 5) = √50 m/s ≈ 7.07 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Half the PE converts to KE: ½mv² = ½mgh → v = √(gh) = √50 m/s.

questions.question_text: A body of mass 2 kg slides down a frictionless incline of height 5 m starting from rest. The KE at the bottom is (g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_correct: By conservation: KE = mgh = 2 × 10 × 5 = 100 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All PE converts to KE on a frictionless surface: KE = mgh = 100 J.

questions.question_text: The work done by friction on a body sliding on a surface is:
questions.explanation_correct: Kinetic friction always opposes the direction of motion, so the angle between friction and displacement is 180°, making work negative.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since friction acts opposite to displacement, W = Fd cos 180° = −Fd, which is always negative.

questions.question_text: Power is defined as:
questions.explanation_correct: Power is the rate of doing work: P = W/t (average) or P = dW/dt (instantaneous).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Power = work/time. Force × displacement is work. Force × time is impulse.

questions.question_text: One horsepower (HP) is approximately equal to:
questions.explanation_correct: 1 HP = 746 W (approximately).
questions.explanation_incorrect: By definition, 1 horsepower = 746 watts, not 500 or 1000 W.

questions.question_text: A machine does 1000 J of work in 5 s. Its power is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Power = work/time = 1000/5 = 200 W.

questions.question_text: The instantaneous power delivered by a force F to a body moving with velocity v is:
questions.explanation_correct: Instantaneous power P = F·v = Fv cos θ, where θ is the angle between force and velocity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: P = dW/dt = F·(dx/dt) = F·v.

questions.question_text: A car of mass 1000 kg accelerates from rest to 20 m/s in 10 s. The average power delivered by the engine is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Average power = ΔKE/t = (½ × 1000 × 20²)/10 = 200000/10 = 20 kW.

questions.question_text: A pump lifts 100 kg of water per minute to a height of 30 m. The power of the pump is (g = 10 m/s²):
A vehicle of mass 500 kg moves at constant velocity 72 km/h against a resistive force of 500 N. The power of the engine is:
questions.explanation_correct: 72 km/h = 20 m/s. At constant velocity, driving force = resistive force = 500 N. P = Fv = 500 × 20 = 10000 W = 10 kW.

questions.question_text: In a perfectly elastic collision:

options.text: Both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved

questions.explanation_correct: In elastic collisions, both total momentum and total kinetic energy of the system are conserved.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Elastic collisions conserve both momentum and KE. Inelastic conserve only momentum.

questions.question_text: In a perfectly inelastic collision, the colliding bodies:

options.text: Stick together and move as one

questions.explanation_correct: In a perfectly inelastic collision, the two bodies stick together and move with a common velocity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Maximum KE loss occurs when bodies stick together. They move with combined mass.

questions.question_text: A ball of mass 1 kg moving at 10 m/s collides head-on elastically with a stationary ball of mass 1 kg. After collision, the first ball:
questions.explanation_correct: In elastic collision between equal masses, the first ball stops and the second moves with the velocity of the first.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For equal masses in elastic collision: v₁ = 0, v₂ = u₁ = 10 m/s. The velocities exchange.

questions.question_text: A body of mass 2 kg moving at 6 m/s collides with a stationary body of mass 4 kg. If the collision is perfectly inelastic, the common velocity is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: For perfectly inelastic collision: v = (2×6 + 4×0)/(2+4) = 12/6 = 2 m/s.

questions.question_text: In the above perfectly inelastic collision (2 kg at 6 m/s hitting stationary 4 kg), the loss in kinetic energy is:
questions.explanation_correct: KE_initial = ½×2×36 = 36 J. KE_final = ½×6×4 = 12 J. Loss = 36 − 12 = 24 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Loss = ½ × m₁m₂/(m₁+m₂) × (u₁−u₂)² = ½ × 8/6 × 36 = 24 J.

questions.question_text: A body of mass m collides elastically with another body of mass 2m at rest. The fraction of KE transferred to the second body is:
questions.explanation_correct: Fraction transferred = 4m₁m₂/(m₁+m₂)² = 4×m×2m/(3m)² = 8m²/9m² = 8/9.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For elastic collision, fraction of KE transferred = 4m₁m₂/(m₁+m₂)² = 8/9.

questions.question_text: The coefficient of restitution for a perfectly elastic collision is:
questions.explanation_correct: e = 1 for perfectly elastic collision. e = 0 for perfectly inelastic. For real collisions, 0 < e < 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coefficient of restitution e = (relative speed of separation)/(relative speed of approach) = 1 for elastic.

questions.question_text: A ball is dropped from height h onto a floor with coefficient of restitution e. The height to which it rebounds is:
questions.explanation_correct: Speed before impact = √(2gh). Speed after = e√(2gh). Rebound height = (e√(2gh))²/(2g) = e²h.
questions.explanation_incorrect: v_rebound = e × v_impact. h_rebound = v²_rebound/(2g) = e²v²_impact/(2g) = e²h.

questions.question_text: Work done by the centripetal force on a body moving in a circle is:
questions.explanation_correct: Centripetal force is always perpendicular to the velocity (displacement direction), so work = Fd cos 90° = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since centripetal force ⊥ velocity at all times, it does no work. It only changes direction.

questions.question_text: The relationship between conservative force and potential energy is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a conservative force, F = −dU/dx. The force is the negative gradient of potential energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The negative sign indicates that force acts in the direction of decreasing potential energy.

questions.question_text: A heavy body moving at 2 m/s collides head-on with a light body at rest. In elastic collision, the light body moves at approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: When a very heavy body hits a very light one elastically, the light body moves at approximately twice the heavy body's velocity: v₂ ≈ 2u₁ = 4 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For M >> m in elastic collision: v₂ = 2Mu₁/(M+m) ≈ 2u₁ = 4 m/s.

questions.question_text: The power of a motor that can lift 200 kg of water per minute to a height of 15 m is (g = 10 m/s²):
Kinetic energy is always:
questions.explanation_correct: KE = ½mv² is always ≥ 0 because mass is positive and v² is always non-negative.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since both m > 0 and v² ≥ 0, kinetic energy can never be negative.

questions.question_text: Momentum is conserved in:

options.text: All collisions (when no external force acts)

questions.explanation_correct: Momentum is conserved in all types of collisions as long as no net external force acts on the system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Conservation of momentum applies to elastic, inelastic, and perfectly inelastic collisions alike.

questions.question_text: The restoring force in a spring obeying Hooke's law is:
questions.explanation_correct: Hooke's law: F = −kx, where the negative sign indicates the force opposes the displacement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The restoring force is proportional to displacement and opposite in direction: F = −kx.

questions.question_text: A ball of mass 1 kg is thrown upward with 10 m/s. At a height of 3 m its kinetic energy is (g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_correct: Total energy = ½mv² = 50 J. PE at 3 m = mgh = 30 J. KE = 50 − 30 = 20 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By conservation: KE = Total − PE = 50 − 30 = 20 J.
